description.text: These are high-resolution scans of two sixteenth-century Austrian woodcuts of plants, suitable for use as demonstration objects for courses on printing, the history of printing, or the history of science.

These blocks were originally commissioned for a mid-16th century publication of an ancient treatise on medicinal plants by Dioscorides, entitled De Materia Medica. This book was translated into Czech and German (and later Latin and Italian) by a renowned Viennese doctor and naturalist, Pietro Andreas Mattioli, with the support of the Hapsburg emperor Ferdinand I. Mattioli hired Giorgio Liberale de Udine and Wolfgang Meyerpeck to design and illustrate these blocks, of which there were originally over 600. They are considered some of the best woodblock prints of their era. These two are now in the collection of the University of Illinois at Urbana-Champaign's Rare Book and Manuscript Library.

After 3D-printing this object, it can be used for a simple demonstration of historic book illustration processes, and is suitable for printing from directly. The scan is high-resolution enough to show the knife marks of the original carver.

description.text:
I wanted the utility of a Lego like part, but the pretty almost steampunk effect of spokes, and I wanted it all to be autogenerated.

The default values are NOT Lego compatible, but you should be able to put in Lego compatible values with the customizer.

If you need a wheel bigger than 100mm, scale back your values, then scale up the part before printing it.

Be careful as you adjust values. There are still some bugs.

Bugs I fixed:
Wheel diameter cannot be less than hub diameter.
Hub diameter cannot be less than axle diameter.
The formula for the spokes was having issues when spoke count got less than 5.
High values of Rim thickness produced off parts.

Known Bugs:
Trying to Fix the graphical glitch with the customizer preview.

For your reference:
http://www.cailliau.org/Alphabetical/L/Lego/Dimensions/General%20Considerations/
LEGO AxleDia = 4.9
LEGO HubWidth=6.2

title: Wanhao i3 v2.1 CiiiCooler adapter/Ultimate X Belt Tensioner combo

description.text:
I wanted to use both the CiiiCooler and the Ultimate X Belt tensioner on my v2.1 i3, but the belt tensioner would not fit with the CiiiCooler adapter in place. I attempted to cut down the tensioner to fit, but gave up and combined them into one piece. I also opened up the area the nut goes into so I could use a lock nut instead.

Thanks to Pawpawpaw85 for letting me use the adapter he designed for this remix. The original part and the CiiCooler to go with it can be found here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2004629

Nope, The arc that connects the adapter to the tensioner is ~1.5mm short. As a result the block of the tensioner can not lie flat on the plate between the bearing holders as it is supposed to in order to tighten stable in place.
I eventually cut the adapter from the block with the saw, and it still makes a perfect adapter for the Ciii - I will use it like that. Suggest that you do a variant without the tensioner, see the picture what I am talking about:

remixed_from.title: Original Prusa i3 MK2 E3D Titan Aero Upgrade

title: Titan Aero Prusa i3 MK2 Mount

description.text:
Update: 26042017

From comments that have been made it seems that not using the spacer and modifying the firmware

define Y_MAX_POS 195 // modified from 210 to 195

gives the correct / usable positioning.

All the other firmware modifications from below should still be used.

Update: 29032017

Deleted v1 mount.

19mm Rear Spacer Added. To account for Y-Axis Offset as per original, but may not be required.

You loose 20mm along the Y-Axis but gain 5mm along the Z-Axis. The X-Axis is unaffected.

All the original wrap around mounts work with this bracket.

Firmware Mods. Required ( Not Checked ).

// Home position
define MANUAL_X_HOME_POS 0
define MANUAL_Y_HOME_POS -22.2
define MANUAL_Z_HOME_POS 0.15

// Travel limits after homing
define X_MAX_POS 250
define X_MIN_POS 0
define Y_MAX_POS 210 // may need to be modified to 195 see above
define Y_MIN_POS -22.2
define Z_MAX_POS 215
define Z_MIN_POS 0.15

define X_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER 0
define Y_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER 25
define Z_PROBE_OFFSET_FROM_EXTRUDER 0

//Titan Aero Steps/mm
define DEFAULT_AXIS_STEPS_PER_UNIT {100,100,3200/8,418.5}

Update: 27032017

Remixed version for the BlTouch.

Titan Aero Prusa i3 MK2 BLTouch Mount

Update: 27032017

Uploaded a v2 file with tweaked holes for the Pinda mount, You should probably use this file instead of the original.

Description

This is a Remix of @GregoryHolloway's Original Prusa i3 MK2 E3D Titan Aero Upgrade, I decided i would prefer to be able to just mount the new assembly to the original carriage as i use a modified version with bearing clamps. The mounting holes should match any of the Prusa i3 MK2 Carriage variants that use the original 2 mounting holes.

There is also a 3rd connection point where the original carriage connected to the direct drive motor.

The design also tries to keep some of the useful cable routing.

I haven't printed this as yet but it should work ok, also it includes the newer style MK2S Pinda mount.

Does this setup require the pancake motor?

comments.text:
I can now answer my own questions (having just finished building one of these):
-no, it doesn't require the pancake motor, and you can use whichever size motor you like, but you have to choose the right spacing for the motor to get the blower fan mounted correctly behind it using the mounts created for the fan in the post linked.
-the blower does not hit the left z screw or any part of the x-carriage assembly
-the probe is not in the original location, which is why the firmware needs updating
-Yes, it does require a firmware update to function correctly.

comments.text: PROBLEM: The holes for the square nuts for the probe on your model are only 1.87mm thick(measuring printed model) and the thickness of the physical square nut is 2.33mm, and the holes on the Prusa i3 MK2 are about 2.48mm (measuring the printed parts included).  I would suggest opening up these holes about 0.6mm to fit the nuts properly.
comments.author: tomasro

comments.text: Hi there thanks for downloading and trying it out, i actually just printed mine last night so just did a quick check of the holes on my part and they measured 2.4mm and 2.36mm when printed this was in PETG @ 0.2mm layer heights and 30% infill. i also checked the original drawing and the holes are the same size as Prusa uses for square nuts 2.5mm x 6.2mm.
comments.author: tomasro

comments.text: I used PLA+ with 0.2mm layer height and 30% infill.  The printed width for the square nuts for connecting to the part cooling fan bracket are 2.4 +/- but the probe square nut holes were very small (I measured under 1.9mm, but it's in a difficult spot to measure with digital calipers).  I oriented the print, with the long mounting surface that would connect to the MK2 carriage, facing down on the bed, which means the holes for the nuts for the probe would be printed just fine.

description.text: A collection of Fidget Twisters based off of an original design by Devin Montes. These are the four showcased in his most recent YouTube video in his Twister series. I decided to release mine now that I know he is also releasing his twister designs. They're not exactly pocket-sized, but they show off how any shape will work as a twister design as long as your printer can handle it. They are designed to all be about 45 degree overhangs so they print with no supports if your settings are dialed in for your filament. Feel free to give one or more a print and leave feedback and/or suggestions for new twisters. Hope you like them!

No

No

Resolution:

.2mm

Infill:

10-20

Notes:

Print the shell first, preferably in a different color than the core.
Make sure to sand away the bottom of the shell to remove the edge that forms on the buildplate.
When the core is more than halfway done printing, pause the print and slide the shell on.
This is a good time to make sure the shell fits correctly before finishing the longer core print.
If the shell slides on easily without much force, resume the print.
When it is finished, the shell will be held onto the core by the end caps.

These can be re-sized up and down, just remember smaller sizes will stick more and larger sizes will slip more. I tried to make them optimal size for printing, but during my original printing process I did some on-the-fly resizing that I didn't save. With this, as well as variation in printers and materials/shrinkage, you may have to tweak them a bit.

remixed_from.title: 2-in-1 fan duct: extruder and filament cooler for E3D V6 and others

description.text:
I could not get my printer to make a solid fan mount that stayed attached and secure to the heat barrel of my e3d v6 clone so I decided to make two adapters that attach directly to the stock 30mm fan mounts. These are specifically for 60mm fans.

The PLA fan mount has an additional vent for PLA printing or any material that requires immediate cooling. The ABS mount only vents to the heat spreader. The adapter mounts with just two screws and I used a little kapton tape to seal any remaining gap between the mount and adapter.

The ABS one can likely be printed on its bottom flat side though I printed both versions with the fan hole facing down. As long as you print them slowly they should print fine. I printed both versions in ABS though there should be no problem using PLA.

remixed_from.title: Improved filament feeder for HICTOP 3d printer with filament monitor switch

title: Hictop spool holder and filament sensor lift kit

description.text:
Upon assembling my 3DP-17, i observed the filament sensor was too low to be useful, It limited the height of the print space because it is in the path of the printhead carriage. By raising the height of the spool and sensor, the full print height is available to be used. Also the angle of the filament when the head is at the extreme left hand position is lowered as well, the sensor housing incorporates roller guides to ease the passage of the filament as it moves through the sensor.

the spool adapter cones accept standard 608 bearing and use a8mm rod or a 5/16" rod, either works fine. I used 4-40 bolts and nuts to secure the rollers and the switch and mounting hardware was striped from the original housing that was in the printer kit. the sensor arm bracket and the vertical brackets are snugged onto the riser block with M3x35 bolts and wing nuts. The riser bar uses M5x15 bolts and M5 T nuts.

This is a redesign of Josef's Y-Belt Idler for i3 MK2 extended by a tensioner.

Tensioner is realized by one M3 locking nut and one M3x12 hexagon socket screw.

The locking nut needs to be built into the Y-Belt Idler from the bottom side with the locking ring of the nut in the direction of the M8 threaded rod of i3 MK2's frame.
Afterwards screw M3x12 screw in the nut from the back side of the idler.

Install the Y-Belt Idler in the frame, strain the Y-Belt and finaly fix the idler with original M8 nuts and washers.

The idler is designed in a way that it does not impact heat bed movement or minimize printing area respectively.

description.text:
Small update to Tony_921's great x gantry replacement. Adjusted the holes on the left side pieces to allow easy mounting of a Z -axis endstop on the bottom. Update 4/21: Added a Z Endstop Adjuster for those who need it. It has M3 holes to attach it under where the Z Endstop is located. I use it without an added screw on top.

Kurt's football from "Heathers" and "Heathers: The Musical". I made this to be played as a knight in a "Heathers" chess set. Kurt and Ram have the exact same piece (besides the name) because they are literally the exact same character. In both the movie and show Kurt is the quarterback of the football team and an insufferable jerk. He and Ram say extremely homophobic things and then spread a rumor about Veronica. This rumor leads J.D. to tricking Veronica into killing the pair and making it look like a gay suicide pact.

"You have a zit right there."

This is a case for mounting an LCD smart controller with a built in  SD card reader on a 3D printer. Currently used in the TubularBot printer, would also work with compatible Prusa i3 printers. The case includes a slot for the SD card to pass through. Comes in two parts, which are bound together by M3 hex screws at each corner. There are two mounting holes on the bottom for binding it to a metal or wood frame.

There were already a lot of shelf pins on Thingiverse, but I wanted something beefier.
It is for a 4.7 mm (0.185 in) peg hole that is 11 mm deep. It includes an optional mounting point for a wood screw - and the steel variants will allow you to use a 15 mm M3 SHCS to take most of the load of the shelf. I have no liability for however you may use this design, you should not expect any guarantee of structural adequacy regardless of application.

When I printed it the 'sleeve' for the steel peg was not fully attached to the bolt - but it did not matter because it threaded over it just fine.   
I have no particular recommendations for the print settings.

remixed_from.title: QUBD : Bowden style x-carriage with hot-end metal holder

title: QU-BD Bowden X Carriage for E3D V6 w/ X Endstop

description.text:
This X-carriage is loosely based on Tony_921 x-carriage with a metal holder. I have made three major modifications. I printed this at 0.2mm height with ABS and 20% infill.

  1. Shifted the bearing holders slightly to the right. This adds about 5-10mm of extra printing room on the x-axis depending on which parts you use for your right gantry. It makes the part painful to print (about 3.5 hours at 20mm/s) but really worth it for those people trying to maximize print volume.

  2. Moved the belt grip and metal holder holes up quite a bit. This makes the belt perfectly tight when using Tony_921's narrow right gantry. Moving the metal holder up increases Z-axis build space and allows me to use my z endstop mod(http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2201664) without an adjuster.

  3. Merged a X-axis endstop mount directly into the carriage itself. You can easily add an x endstop with the bracket and adjuster.

Metal Holder:
http://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00G9FQYTG

Got a new water cooler and wanted my daughter to be able to use it by herself. She couldn't reach the cupboard where we keep her cups, so I designed this cupholder to hang off the cooler.   
The holder is designed to fit our cooler and plastic kids cups from Ikea. I added some thin supports that can be clipped off with diagonal cutters.  I've included the Openscad design file so it can be resized.
Sliced at Medium quality in Makerware (0.2 mm layer height, 10% infill). Printed on a Replicator 2 in PLA and then cut off the supports with diagonal cutters.

This is a custom lightsaber that I designed for a cosplay for con season this year. The entire length of the saber handle is about 11.5 inches, making it easy to hold and comfortable in the hand. This model is intended to be printed as three parts: the top, shaft, and pommel, in order to ensure the best print quality. The vent holes and grip holes turned out great when I printed this on a MendelMax 3d Printer earlier this month, using a .2mm thickness.

title: Isosurface Burr Bowl
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text: Once again an isosurface, this time to produce something that to me looks very like the traditional wood crafts idea of taking a wooden burr nodule from a tree and making a decorative bowl from it. My wife has described it as being very tactile and pleasing to hold.

Printer:

Eaglemoss Vector3

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

10%

Notes:

The model is in the STL file upside down so that it requires no supports.

I started with some code I give my students to help them start 3D graphics projects. This helps them create models in Vertex and Index Buffers programmatically. I then grabbed the Marching Cubes function from here, and used it so that I could feed in an equation and get out a Vertex Buffer containing a given iso-surface of that equation, display it and then spits out a basic obj file.

After much playing with various equations I got a mostly spherical object with strange tubes running through it, from the equation given below. This was then put into Netfabb, where I sliced it in half and also a sneaky slice on the bottom to allow it stand better. Lastly, a sphere was take away from the object using Boolean operators.

author: igor1985

description.text:
25W accidental zap  
I have a super-manly Chinese laser with no door switch or other protection. I thought the device was done cutting, and began popping out cutouts with a toothpick to see if they had cut through. It shuttled down after a final data load and my hand ended up in the beam path for about a second until I jumped away. Zap was 50% power of a 50W.  
Conclusion: It hurt. Say a large size soldering iron burn. Beam path is probably not a dismemberment risk, but at 50W even the beam path would offer easy 2nd or 3rd degree burns. Focused beam is quite likely an ER trip and/or permanent life change.  
Thought you might like to see what actually happens in a hobby laser strike, to prove that you should be patient, and keep out of the work area!

title: Tunze Care Magnet (Long) Blade holder
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
The Tunze Care Magnet is a scraper used to remove algae from a fish aquarium. Tunze's design is great in that it prevents sand from being trapped between the scraper and your aquarium glass, helping to prevent scratches.

The blades are replaceable, but there is a weakness in how the blades are attached to the scraper body. Over time the blue plastic piece will warp, which allows the blade to sit loosely and not be as effective. My design is more rigid and more securely snaps into place holding the blade tightly.

Edits:
3/25/2017 - added a half circle to make it fit easier when snapping into place.

description.text:
When I was a kid, I used to like drawing patterns on graph paper. One of my favorite was to draw strait lines from [0,(n-i+1)] to [i,0] for i = 1 to n. When n is large enough (~10), the pattern produces an outer surface that looks curved. Place one at each corner of a square produces the attached designs.  
I translated the design into 3d. Attached files (n = 10) include two different thicknesses (the thick stands nicely by itself) and and two different sizes with a loop on the corner for mounting on a wall or as a pendant.
Sliced in Makerware with 0.2 mm layer height and 0% infill. Printed on a Replicator 2 in PLA.

title: Honeywell 5816 Replacement Magnet
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a replacement magnet holder for a Honeywell 5816 Wireless Sensor. It's designed to use cheap round rare-earth magnets in place of the larger bar magnet the original uses.

This should be pretty close size-wise, as I modeled it off an original magnet.

Printer Brand:

LulzBot

Printer:

TAZ 6

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.22

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Sliced with Cura Lulzbot Edition. Standard ABS settings (0.22mm height, 20% infill)

It should be a fairly easy print. There may be some bridging issues if your printer isn't tuned nicely, but it actually helps hold the magnet in place.

I used these magnets (http://www.harborfreight.com/10-piece-rare-earth-magnets-67488.html) and it seems to work for me.

Use a flat-blade screwdriver to push the magnet into the holder. Be careful not to slip and stab yourself.

Mount with double-sided sticky tape (I recommend 3M VHB-style tape).

Designed in FreeCad 0.16. The -2.75 is in reference to the height of the opening. The magnet measures 2mm, but it is nearly impossible to wedge the magnet in with a 2mm opening. I redesigned it twice before settling on the 2.75mm opening. YMMV.

title: Dual parking carriage extruder Prusa i3 | E3D & 1730 FMH

description.text:
This design is based on Jellebross' and 3D Proto's design.
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1446731
http://3d-proto.de/

Summary

Dual parking carriage extruder.
It uses one E3D Lite6 hotend and one 1730 Full metal hotend.
The E3D Lite6 (V6 fits as well) for support and materials up to 240C and the 1730 hotend for materials up to 400C. On each carriage, there is a 40mm high-airflow server fan to keep the hotend cool. Aswell as a part cooling fan.
It uses two 12V 20N electromagnets to pick up and drop off the carriages. Two neodymium magnets on either side of the Z-slides hold them in place.
The two electromagnets are mounted to the mid-carriage, as well as an inductive sensor to level the buildplate.

Things you'll need:

  • E3D v6 or E3D Lite6 hotend
    http://e3d-online.com/
  • 1730 Full Metal Hotend
    http://www.1730hotend.com/1730-full-metal-hotend-standard-edition-basic-1-75-mm.html
  • 2x 40x40x20 mm 12V cooling fan
    https://nl.aliexpress.com/item/YOC-Hot-New-Black-Plastic-12V-DC-40mm-20mm-2-Wire-Computer-PC-CPU-Cooling-Case/32689866369.html
  • 2x 40x40x7 mm 12V cooling fan
    https://nl.aliexpress.com/item/New-4007-40MM-3CM-fan-40-40-7mm-5v-0-15A-12V-0-1A-The-graphics/32451807299.html
  • 2x Pneumatic fitting M6
    https://nl.aliexpress.com/item/2-pcs-lot-PC4-M6-Pneumatic-Straight-Fitting-Connector-for-4mm-OD-tubing-M6-6mm-Reprap/32539393164.html
  • LJ12A3-4-Z/BX-5V inductieve proximity sensor
    https://nl.aliexpress.com/item/M12-4mm-detection-5VDC-NPN-NO-LJ12A3-4-Z-BX-5V-cylinder-inductive-proximity-sensor-switch/32553311139.html
  • 2x 20N 12V electromagnet
    https://nl.aliexpress.com/item/P20-15-2-5kg-Electric-Lifting-Magnet-Electromagnet-Solenoid-Lift-Holding-DC-6V-12V-24V/32656605538.html
  • 10x LM8LUU bearing
    https://nl.aliexpress.com/item/Free-Shipping-12pcs-lot-LM8UU-8mm-Linear-Bushing-CNC-Linear-Bearings/32434013744.html
  • 2 or 4-channel relay board
    https://nl.aliexpress.com/item/1pcs-lot-4-channel-relay-module-4-channel-relay-control-board-with-optocoupler-Relay-Output-4/32340914033.html
  • 12x Neodymium magnet 6 x 3mm
    https://nl.aliexpress.com/item/100pcs-N35-Mini-Dia-6x3mm-Neodymium-Magnets-Strong-Round-Magnet-Industrial-Magnet/1923066185.html

  • 2x metal disk Ø21mm x 2mm thick
  • 2x Diode 1000V / 1A
  • 16x ISO4762 M3 x 35 bolt
  • 6x ISO4762 M3 x 8 bolt
  • 4x ISO4762 M3 x 20 bolt
  • 4x ISO4762 M3 x 25 bolt
  • 2x ISO4762 M4 x 30 bolt
  • 2x ISO4762 M4 x 16 bolt
  • 2x M4 nut

Wiring

See 3D proto's wiring diagram here:
http://www.3d-proto.de/public/img/DualParkExtSetup.png

Slicer settings:

Very few firmware changes are required. The pick up and drop off process is done in Gcode.

Simplify3D

{IF NEWTOOL=0} G1 X215.000 F5500
{IF NEWTOOL=0} M42 P11 S255
{IF NEWTOOL=0} G1 X0.000 F5500
{IF NEWTOOL=0} M42 P5 S0

{IF NEWTOOL=1} G1 X0.00 F5500
{IF NEWTOOL=1} M42 P5 S255
{IF NEWTOOL=1} G1 X215.000 F5500
{IF NEWTOOL=1} M42 P11 S0

Cura 15.04

See: https://github.com/Helixmedia3D/KT8Post-Postprocessor
Use these settings for Cura Custom Gcode: https://github.com/Helixmedia3D/KT8DualPlus/blob/master/KT8%20Cura%20Gcode.md
(Cura 2.X isn't supported!)


Updates:
16-11-17: Added a right E3D carrier, so dual E3D v6 or Lite6 is now possible.

Contact me if you have any questions.

description.text: This thing is a thumbscrew adjustable z-stop bracket for a Mendel.

Print the parts and assemble to replace the printed spring z-stop adjustment. I was never happy with the range of springyness of the printed spring, and having to adjust the z-stop with an allen key (although very rare) was annoying. Remove the printed spring, and replace with this thing. Production:
Print the parts.
1 of each.
Skip the bush it doesn't do anything. I fitted two to mine, but i will take them off when i need to pull it apart again.
The base and cap have "mouse ears". Cut them off after printing. The base holds two upright m4x45 bolts as guides. Insert the bolts up through the base - it has recesses for the heads. I have fitted bushes on the guides to allow them to be bolted into the base with m4 nuts. They are not long enough to fasten the guides with nuts but it doesn't seem to need it at the moment. Fitting:

  • Remove the printed spring and sensor.

  • Remove the nuts holding the two x-axis idler bearings and bolt the base down on those bolts. Remember the base is not reversible, put it on the right way around to allow the adjustment bolt to go through to the captive nut.

  • Put the opto limit switch bracket on the cap.
  • Glue the knob onto the top of the adjustment bolt - from your original system.
  • Put the bolt through the opto bracket and cap.
  • Fit the spring (of your choice) and slide the cap assembly onto the guides and screw in the adjustment screw.
    • It should be nearly the same size as the original. If necessary adjust your flag to get the range of adjustment for your extruder. Usage:
  • Adjust and tweak at will now that you can do it with your fingers.

description.text:
A filament guide insert for a E3D extruder.

I made the Davinci to E3D conversion but was frustrated with loading the filament. The extruder I purchased (knockoff) had a Bowden PTFE connector that made it difficult to load filament.

I created this insert to ease my pain. As you will see in the cutaway picture the throat is tapered from about 5 mils to about 2 mils.

This makes loading the filament pretty easy.

Printer:

Repetier/Davinci with E3D Extruder

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

The insert is saved 'up side down' and it prints on my bed pretty well without the use of rafts or a brim - but it's just on the harry edge of needing some adhesion help. I would not be surprised if you needed a brim.

I have printed with both ABS and PLA although the insert I use is PLA and have had no issues.

As mentioned before this is for a knockoff extruder that uses a PTFE tube to prevent filament freeze. To properly size the length of the PFTE tube I screwed the insert in with no tube. Calculated the total depth - the depth that the insert went in. Cut the tube (a little long), screwed it together. I don't think this hast to be a perfect length match, the PTFE tube just has to enter the end of the insert so it doesn't move side to side.

Now inserting the filament is easy. Just get it within the 5mm opening and push it in.

title: Sensor-Housing for LoLin NodeMCU V3(ESP8266) + DHT-11/22

description.text:
Started home automation with openHAB using sensors based on ESP8266 and DHT.
But I found no fitting houses on thingiverse for my needs.
Some didn't fit the boards. Some are bad designs disturbing the measurement by the heat of ESP.

This design is a bit rough, but it works. Easy to print and may be shower-proof (and leaky) enough to stay on the outside wall, too.
I designed no holes for screws, because I like to mold the pins with a hot iron.

May be there will an upgrade to cover the open space on the wiring to the DHT. Let's see...

Hope you enjoy the design for your project.
Please upload pics from your print.
I will appreciate our feedback.

(Have a look at https://www.letscontrolit.com/wiki/index.php/ESPEasy. Programming is a nice hobby, but there are cool solutions out there already.)

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Clone

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

20%

Notes:

The adjustment/molding pins are designed right. But the slicer may be struggles with it.
So in my case cura failed, but slic3r managed the job.

If you you print the "cut-out"-lid with the open side upwards, you will need no support.

Hi Antonio,
the DHT sensor does not get influenced by the NodeMCU.

The DHT of course has his own accuracy...

description.text:
Our multi-color remix of YahooJAPAN's Sphinx!

The single .stl was split apart into multiple files using the Meshmixer "Complex" tool.

Printed with Palette (http://mosaicmanufacturing.com).

This is a split of the original stand. If your 3D printer doesn't have the capable length that the MakerBot does then this is the alternative option.

There are two holes on each piece to be able to put 1/4"W x 1/2"L metal dowel pins to join the two pieces. You may or may not have to use glue to keep the two pieces together.

print_settings.Notes:: I have also reduced the extrusion width just for the contour layer. This is an "expert setting" in Slic3r. Load the flat animal STL file and double-click the object to open a Settings window. In this window you can choose "Load part..." to load the contours on top of the flat animals. Select the contours part and add the option Extrusion Width > Perimeters to set a separate extrusion width. Play around until the preview contains all details.

description.text:
This is a 3D-printable puzzle made from Escher’s Plane Filling II, inspired by thing http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:966.

It is printed in three parts:

  1. black animals
  2. white animals
  3. frame

The animal STL files are available in two versions each. One including the contours as a 0.2 mm layer on top of the surfece, the other with flat surface and a separate STL file with the contours to add-on. A separate STL for contours can be useful for dual color printing or separate print settings for the fine details of the contours.

Dual color printing can be done even with a single extruder by changing the filament at 3.2 mm height. Josef Prusa offers a tool which inserts an M600 G-Code command at a given layer height: http://www.prusaprinters.org/color-print/

Alternatively, the contours can be printed in the same color (see example photo of the dragon) or subtracted to make an engraved contour (see other example photo of the dragon). I would recommend the dual color version, though.

Printer Brand:

Prusa

Printer:

Prusa Mk2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2 mm

Notes:

I have used Slic3r for G-Code generation. In Slic3r, you need to turn on the option Print Settings > Layers and Perimeters > Detect thin walls in order to render the fine details well.

I have also reduced the extrusion width just for the contour layer. This is an "expert setting" in Slic3r. Load the flat animal STL file and double-click the object to open a Settings window. In this window you can choose "Load part..." to load the contours on top of the flat animals. Select the contours part and add the option Extrusion Width > Perimeters to set a separate extrusion width. Play around until the preview contains all details.

title: 80mm active cooling fan mount for Mk7/8 / RepRapGuru Prusa i3 v2
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a mounting kit to add a 80mm computer case fan to your 3d printer as an active cooling fan. This was designed for the RepRapGuru Prusa i3 v2, but it should work with any printer with a Mk7/8 extruder.

I designed the screw holes to work with the extra screws that came with my printer kit. The screw holes should be narrow enough that the screw threads bite into the plastic and hold it in place without need for nuts. Depending on your hardware and printer settings, you may need to adjust the size of the holes or drill out the holes to make them wider.

No supports needed.

Attach the mounting ring
  1. Print the mounting ring and funnel.
  2. Remove the two long screws that hold the extruder fan and heatsink on the extruder assembly. These can be found on the bottom of the front face of the extruder fan. Keep track of any washers or spacers which may fall out.
  3. Place the mounting ring between the extruder fan and the heatsink as shown in the pictures, with the sideways-pointing screw holes on the right side of the ring.
  4. Screw the two long screws back in. This will firmly attach the mounting ring to the extruder assembly.
Attach the funnel & 80mm fan
  1. Snip off the two thin support structures on the outside of the funnel, next to the two screw holes that stick out at an odd angle.
  2. Using the 4 screws that should have come with your 80mm fan (or whatever screws you have on hand), attach the 80mm fan to the back of the funnel. Make sure your fan is rotated properly, so that air will blow through the funnel. Also rotate the fan so that the wires come out of the fan on one of the top corners.
  3. Using two screws, attach the funnel/fan assembly to the mounting ring. The screw threads should bite into the plastic to hold it in place.
  4. Snip off the molex connector from the end of your 80mm fan wires and hook up the wires to the D9 terminals on your RAMPS board.

author: ransoing

description.text: This is a 1:1 scale replica of one of the turbine blades that powered the fuel and oxidizer pumps for the V-2 rocket. The rocket had a hydrogen peroxide reactor/rocket engine, which then directed the hot gases onto 172 of these blades, and turned a shaft that drove the main pumps. Among other things, it was the first man-made object to pass the Karman line and enter space, and also the first man-made object to travel at hypersonic speeds. http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/V-2_rocket The archive of the German Museum has all of the original drawings of the V-2 Rocket, If you look at the drawings they are occasionally marked up in english and have U.S. Army stamps on them. You can see the translated full archive of all drawings here: http://translate.google.com/translate?depth=1&hl=en&rurl=translate.google.com&sl=de&tl=en&u=http://www.digipeer.de/index.php%3Fstatic%3D52

These were printed on an Objet. I would love to see if anyone could make this on an FDM printer. You will probably want to scale it up to get all of the detail as they are about 1 inch tall.  
If you want ultra-realism, make it out of 6063 Aluminum, Upload the .SLDPRT to Firstcut, it will be a little over $100 for one and $70 if you order a bunch.

comments.text: Gyroscopes fascinate me. They are oddly difficult to find. I wanted to do some experiments with them and wanted to see if I could actually print one. So far, the prototypes work well.
comments.author: ProfessorMajack

comments.text: Thats awesome. Do fidget spinners work like gyroscopes?
comments.author: Gannan

comments.text: Yes, fidget spinners work like gyroscopes. You can look up "gyroscope" on Wikipedia.com and it will explain them pretty well. Gyroscopes work because of a principle known as conservation of angular momentum, which, in layman's terms, means that the more angular momentum (the faster it spins, the more mass is has, or the more mass is oriented away from the rotation axis) an object has the harder it is to tilt it. Imagine trying to push a moving bullet away from its path (assuming, of course, that there's no danger of hurting yourself). When a bullet is not moving, it's very easy to push because it technically has no momentum, but a bullet shot from a gun is harder to move because it's moving rapidly, giving it enough momentum to be lethal. Now, imagine those bullets are arranged in a circle, and every time you try to move one bullet that motion tilts the circular plane they're arranged on. Now, whenever you try to push one bullet you also have to move all the other bullets with it, meaning you have to overcome the momentum of all the bullets, not just one. This is basically what a gyroscope is: A weighted ring designed to spin on a defined axis (so, a wheel) so that when it spins the angular momentum prevents any force perpendicular to the wheel or that would change the angle of the rotation axis and counteracts those forces. This means the gyroscope will prevent any forces that would cause it to tilt (including gravity, which is how it remains upright) and try to move itself back to its original position. Notice that gyroscopes can also be tilted instead of upright. The wheel's momentum simply keeps the axis at its current angle, not just a 90 degree angle. Tops work the same way, so gyroscopes are really just professional, science-y tops.
comments.author: ProfessorMajack

comments.text: I don't know why the text in my reply looks different.  I tried to change it, but I don't think I can.  Sorry it's so hard to read.
comments.author: death_angel

comments.text: I can read it and I thought that the spinners work on the same principle, but i'd rather ask than assume.
comments.author: death_angel

comments.text: Yes, gyroscopes work on the same principal as fidget spinners. You can just look up "gyroscope" on Wikipedia and it will explain them pretty well, but I'll try to explain it for you. Gyroscopes work because of the law of the conservation of angular momentum (I think that's right, but I'm not sure), which, in layman's terms, means that the more angular momentum (the faster it spins, the heavier it is, or the further the mass is oriented away from the spin axis) the more force is required to tilt it. For this reason, gyroscopes are used often in stabilizers in things like airplane compasses and robots that travel on one or two wheels (keeps it balanced or tells it when it's unbalanced so it can then balance itself). Imagine trying to push a moving bullet (assume there's no danger of hurting yourself, of course). It's very easy to move a bullet that is not moving, but once it's shot out of a gun it would be very difficult to deflect it. Now, imagine those bullets are moving in a circle, and whenever you try to move one bullet it tilts the circle, meaning you have to overcome both that bullet's momentum and the momentum of all the other bullets. That's basically what the wheel on a gyroscope is, a weighted ring that spins around a defined axis, counteracting any tilting forces, including gravity, which is why it stays upright so easily. Tops work the same way: The more angular momentum it has, the harder it is to tilt it. That's why they stay upright when you spin them, but tilt as they slow down.

International TableTop day in 2017 is April 29th. Find out if your FLGS is holding an even, then print out this trophy for them.

Until I get the official okay from the TableTop people to use their logo this is the Notable Top Day Trophy of Awesome. See what I did there? No Table Top, Notable? Get it?

Create the SVG
  • Take a photo of the meeple from the top.
  • Import the photo into Inkscape.
  • Trace the outline of the meeple.
  • Delete the image from the document. (Important!)
  • Save the SVG file.
Export to OpenSCAD
  • Download the paths2openscad script at GitHub.
  • Move the .inx/.py files to your ~/.config/inkscape/extensions (%APPDATA%/inkscape/extensions for Windows) folder.
  • (Re)start Inkscape.
  • Open the .svg file.
  • Extensions -> Generate from Path -> Paths to OpenSCAD to generate the .scad file.

This step based heavily on safay's tutorial at Instructables.

Export AMF/STL
  • Open the .scad file in OpenSCAD.
  • Export in your preferred format!

title: Glass bed flush fit corner clips for CTC / REPLICATOR 1 CLONES

description.text:
Glass bed (flush fit corner clips) for bevelled glass edged 6 x 9 150mm x 230mm Borosilicate Glass Plate Bed CTC / REPLICATOR1 CLONES.

The glass bed made a massive difference to the quality of my prints. There are plenty of corners available out there but I needed a solution that wouldn’t catch the nozzles as they move to the home axis or return to the bed. This corner clip is designed to sit flush with the surface of the glass bed thus preventing nozzle crash, it grips onto the glass plate using the radius of the bevelled plate edge (no good if you cut your own) typically what you need are pre-cut borosilicate glass plates that you can buy from any popular online market place. The corner clips are slightly narrower than 90 degrees so they can be slightly tensioned by hand onto the glass for better grip and the curvy outer edges not only minimizes scrapes and scratches to your hands while working around the bed but the shape strengthens its structure while under tension.

Once printed the corners are placed directly over the existing bolts on each corner of the bed, there is no need to undo the nuts, there is sufficient length on the end of the threaded bolt for the corner clips and the extra nut to fit in place. You will need to get 4X M3 nuts.

title: monoprice dual extruder / flashforge creator pro z-wobble fix

description.text:
After a year, my printer started to develop z-wobble. The two rods are pressed in pretty tight in the top, the bottom barely grabs them at the bottom (and there's a huge gap that is 35mm tall). By printing a pair of these spacers, it really locks in the rods tight on the bottom.

Ignore the bearings in my photo. I happened to have some 10mm x 26mm x 8mm bearings lying around so I opted to make my bosses a little shorter and use bearings as a solid support.

As far as getting the z-axis out, unscrew the top and bottom, unplug the z-motor underneath. Then I recommend taking off all three outer plastic panels off, removing all the screws for the base platform except the very front (so you can tilt the platform back), then you should be able to slide it out. Also remember to disconnect the 2 connectors from the pcb on the platform.

One other thing I recommend is to TAKE OUT the bearing at the top of the z-axis. I believe that if there is any out of round in the thread, it will translate that into the print. The 2 rods should be defining position, not the motor. If you look at Prusa i3, the posts are fixed strong, but the z-axis motors sort of float.

author: toyotaboy02

description.text:
Cheap BED Level Sensor!! This will only use the sensor wires which don't really have much voltage (around 0.5v). Basically it's a very simple switch, when the 2 m3 screws touch together it signal the board.

Only need 2 m3 screws, 2 washers, one spring, 2 nuts and a print part! Total cost less then 1$ :)

  1. Print the STL provided in this thing. This sensor mount is 12mm diameter, will be able to be mounted on compatible "inductive sensor" or you can screw it where you want using the 2 holes for that mater... I used 20% infill and with support.

  2. Insert a standard nut inside the printed part on the top, then insert a 8mm m3 screw, don't forget to attach on of the sensor wire on this screw.

  3. You need a 20mm m3 screw (put something around that size), before insert the nut, the screw need 2 washers and one sprint, so, insert in that order, washer, spring, washer, the other sensor wire then screw inside the part on the lock nut.

With this sensor, when the leveling is done, it need to be removed to not touch the print, it is the only inconvenient but it work.

Test video: https://youtu.be/IfeVVwbapV8

If you have suggestion for some type of mechanism to be able to retract this sensor without unscrew post your comment :).

description.text:
update 3/31/17 I have included a table, different faceplates, and a fumehood.I would also recommend using a buck converter in lieu of the voltage regulator, mine produced more heat than i thought and was unsafe to put in without a massive heatsink. The buck converter is larger but is easier to wire up and wont burn down your house if you have too much current running through it.** (Videos of it working and the circut are coming)Great one day project(total print time 4-6h/ circuit with voltage reg build time 1h at the most)I made fume extractors all different sizes and shapes and now i feel like i can finally put this project to rest with this version. It uses a 12v 40mm fan, uxcell 2 position vertical slide switch, active carbon pad. If you want a 2mm led you will need the appropriate power supply and voltage regulator combination. I still waiting for my voltage regulators to come in the mail so in the video mine is only connected to my fan at the moment. The tolerance for fitting parts is .2mm, meaning if i have a peg with a circumference 10mm it will go into a hole with the circumference 10.2. That seems to work for most people but if your part fits to loose i can upload a model with tighter tolerances.
DC to DC buck converter

Pieces to join 2 lack tables into a cabinet. Where applicable use #6 countersink wood screws to secure the bracket and leg in place. 2 Leg screws are optional if you wish to leave them out for occasionally completely removing the enclosure. The legs are a snug fit into the brackets. Screws are in locations that are not clearly visible from the exterior of the cabinet or located under the leg itself. The brackets incorporates a glass stop intended to work with these hinges and my other pivot design for vertically hung glass sides.

The cabinet stops allow for modular cabinet disassembly when glass is hinged vertically using my other pivot design (not the pivots here designed horizontal swinging. I know I sometimes want to get at something that has a tendency to need tinkering... like a 3d printer and when that happens the last thing I want to deal with is the cabinet in the way hence the modular break-down design.

Check out my other designs to mix and match components to customize your own cabinet. Everything is there to assemble the entire custom outer enclosure using two Lack tables as the basis.

description.text:
Silicone mold for E3D V6 hotend's
The holes are for string to aid in the separating of this reusable mold.
The mold part needs a 1.6mm rod inserted in the top hole for the nozzle
Used high temp RTV Silicone that is good for up to 316C continuous temperature
The first mold attempt was a failure as the silicone did not fully cure in 24 hours
but the parts that cured are perfect
next will try 72 hours cure time

Update 2017/03/28 Changed orientation of housing to print orientation. Added new V2 housing with holes to aid in curing, added V1.5 and 2 mold for different heater cartridge placement. Also added register for mold to housing orientation.
Testing Different release agents: Dawn Alcohol 1:2mix, Lithium grease, No release agent.
PTFE spray Proved as FAIL Prohibits curing of RTV Silicone!!!

Update 2017/04/08 Dawn Alcohol 1:2 Mix works as release agent(DAWN Dish-washing liquid mixed with alcohol 1:2). Housing with no holes produces nicer boot. Just need longer curing time about 4-6 days depending on humidity!

title: Da Vinci Duo 2.0 Chimera Edition with 200x200 printbed upgrade

description.text:
Updated 12/07/2017
Re-loaded the V4 version of the Chassis that I originally posted back on 08/20/2017. Not sure what happened that the old version ended up back on the posting.

UPDATED 09/10/2017
As promised I have added an PDF document with full step by step instructions with pictures. I have also added a basic chain mount if you wish to eliminate the Extruder Circuit board as I have. Good Luck!!!

UPDATED 08/27/2017
Added new pics of the latest design assembled with all wires fed into the molex connector.

UPDATED 08/22/2017
Added a few pics of the assembled printbed support. You'll need to install the front three screws and then use the holes at the back of the two side brackets as a guide to drill out your Z-axis chassis for the remaining two screws.

UPDATED 08/20/2017
Replaced the Version 3 carriage with an updated Version 4. Realized you couldn't get the Molex pluged in for the cable chain mount. Moved it out and up for clearance.

UPDATED 07/23/2017
I've added a revised version of the carriage with the rear oiling points located in an easier to access location. I've also revised the cable holder to allow for a snap in female Molex connector (part #WM2483-ND) and used with matching male connector (part #WM2489-ND) for easier connecting and disconnecting of the print carriage.

I've also added the files for the front support brackets, support brace, and new thermistor bracket for the 200 x 200 print bed kit. The support brace is to help reduce twisting of the z carriage.. I recommend printing these in ABS with 25% infill as there is some heat transfer to the y carriage plate that has softened PLA when printing with the Bed at Higher temps(found out the hard way during prototyping).

I used a RepRap heated print bed.
http://www.ebay.com/itm/PCB-Heated-Hot-Bed-MK2B-for-RepRap-3D-Printer-pre-wired-for-12V-SMT-LED-soldered/122063000091?ssPageName=STRK%3AMEBIDX%3AIT&_trksid=p2057872.m2749.l2649

A Prusa I3 universal Y-carriage.
http://www.ebay.com/itm/Prusa-i3-Universal-Y-Carriage-Plate-Upgrade-Aluminum-Anodized-for-3D-Printer/121561406955?ssPageName=STRK%3AMEBIDX%3AIT&_trksid=p2057872.m2749.l2649

I did have to modify the carriage by drilling out the 4 corner holes with a 5mm drill bit and taped them to a M6x1 for installing m3 x.5 EZ loks McMaster Carr part # 97120A190.
On the new thermistor bracket there is a breakaway portion. once bolted to the y carriage plate use the hole in the break-away portion as a guide for drilling a 2.5mm hole and tap to M3 x .5 for installation of your rear bed adjustment screw.

All drill bits and taps are also available on McMaster Carr.

Some adhesive backed 3mm think silicone mat.
http://www.ebay.com/itm/12-X12-Black-White-Silicone-Rubber-Sheet-Self-Adhesive-High-Temp-Plate-Mat/122242663272?ssPageName=STRK%3AMEBIDX%3AIT&_trksid=p2057872.m2749.l2649

And an E3D Borosilicate 4mm think 214mm x 214mm glass plate
http://e3d-online.com/Mechanical/Print-Surfaces/Borosilicate-Bed-200x200
held down with some 1/8 mirror clips.
http://www.ebay.com/itm/CRL-Zinc-Plated-Offset-Mirror-Clip-for-1-8-Glass-Pack-of-100-by-CR-Laurence/191936825710?ssPageName=STRK%3AMEBIDX%3AIT&_trksid=p2057872.m2749.l2649.

I've also uploaded a new Repetier file (Repetier_chimera_200.zip) with the proper settings for the 200 x 200 print bed and smaller drip trays. Just unzip this folder to the same location as your current Repetier folder in ArduinoDUE and then open the Repetier_chimera_200.ino file and re-flash your printer.

I will take more assembly pics and provide more instruction as I install this on my next printer. As this is getting long I may create a step by step instructions document and upload that to make things easier.

Should anyone get to this point before I complete the instruction feel free to message me and I will do my best to help you finish the upgrade.

Update 06/12/2017
I've added the files for revised(narrower) left and right drip trays. After trying for several months to make the 200x200mm print bed work with only one original drip tray I have come to the conclusion that it just won't work nor will it fit between the originals. If you want to stick with your 150-200mm print bed then no need to print these. For the 200x200 upgrade you'll need to print both the left and right drip tray and two of the drip boxes.

There are two versions of the drip trays I had little luck with conventional supports for the hanging tabs so I made a version with a more robust support.

More files and a new firmware update will be loaded shortly as well as a parts list for the upgrade, I'm just making a few final tweaks to the mounting brackets and doing some final testing.

Update 03/28/2017
I've added a bracket for relocating the cleaning tab to allow its use with the new print head.. Admittedly I have made so many changes to the firmware that I have uploaded a zip file of my entire Repetier folder. Changes now include Everything from the previous config file as well as removing all movement to the left drip tray and new "Clean" commands to use the newly located cleaning tab to clean both sides of the extruder. I've also turned off the filament sensors and top cover sensors by default. Thanks to Luc at Git-Hub for helping me remove the code for the left drip tray and in setting up the new "Clean" commands.

Update 03/26/2017
I've added a file Configuration.rtf. This is a copy of my Configuration.h file from my Repetier.ino flash. There are nine changes I made to align the print and they are all highlighted in yellow. You will need to open Arduino and load your Repetier.ino file and make these changes to the Configuration.h tab then re-flash your printer. I'm still working to eliminate the load/unload movement to the left drip tray and will post once I figure out how to default both the left and right to the right drip tray.

Warning this is not for the faint at heart... lol Several wires will need to be cut and soldered..

Thanks to Caj for creating a mock up of the Duo carriage(not much of hers left but it gave a good starting point). I posted two versions of the new carriage one has a Chimera logo I found embossed on the side one does not.. This is the only difference in the two files.

You will also notice there are holes directly over the bearings. If you look closely in my pics I have drilled holes in my bearings and ground small journals with spherical diamond dremel bits to allow for easy oiling. I've been using this on my 1.0 for the last 3 months and it seems to work great.

Also there are two small holes on each side of the carriage. These are for easy access to the print head adjustment screws for head leveling.

To save space and make the carriage as small as possible (stage two will hopefully upgrade to a 200x200 print bed) I have relocated the circuit board back on the chassis by adding a mount for the board to the cable chain mount.

The layer cooling fan is designed to have two heat sets installed allowing for thumbscrews to hold it in place for easy removal..

Included are also two versions of fan covers one E3D themed and one with the Chimera Logo.

Parts List:

E3D Chimera Kit
3 - M3x8mm Screws McMaster-Carr #92095A181(used for top three mounting holes in Chimera)
2 - Heat sets M3x.5 McMaster-Carr #94180A331 (mount in layer cooling fan)
2 - M3 Thumb screws McMaster-Carr #92545A111 (for attaching layer cooling fan)
4 - #4 x 1/4 Thread Cutting Screws McMaster-Carr #98273A110 (for mounting circuit board to mount)
2 - #4 x 3/8 Thread cutting screws McMaster-Carr #94629A550 (for belt lock)
2 - M3 x10mm Screws McMaster-Carr # 92125A130 (for cable chain end to mount)
2 - #2 x 3/8 thread cutting screws McMaster-Carr #99461A725 (for carriage cap)
4 - Brass bearings from your original carriage

Installation:
When installing the bearings in the new carriage I recommend test fitting them on the carriage and installing on the rails to make sure the carriage slides smoothly. If they are misaligned the carriage will bind(happened on my first attempt) I made sure the bearings fit loosely and then used JB weld to secure them in place while the carriage was on the rails this way they were set to the riding position. I carefully slid the carriage back and forth to seat the bearings then let it set overnite for the JB weld to set. Once the JB weld has set if you want to do my oil journal mod I would do it now.

*****Make sure to read all Chimera assembly instructions before proceeding****
https://wiki.e3d-online.com/wiki/Cyclops_%26_Chimera_Assembly

Next install the heat sink to the chassis (making sure to install the 4 grub screws for the print head adjustments)with the Three M3 screws and washers provided with the Chimera Kit using the three holes in the back of the carriage. I also used three additional M3x8mm screws to attach the heat sink at the top as well.

Assemble your two print heads as per E3D V6 instructions. Coat the slides with heat gel and insert into the heat sink as pictured. The Chassis is designed to allow for the heater and thermistor cables to feed thru on each side. At this point I installed the original heater connectors on my new Chimera print head heaters and extended the connections on the Thermistors as they were too close to my layer cooling fan and wanted them to move freely for head height adjustment. I had a few JST SM connectors that I installed on the thermistors. All connectors and wire will slide threw the two openings(tightly) in the bottom of the chassis as pictured and the print heads will set nicely facing in opposite directions with the wires feeding up neatly threw the carriage.

I switched to Bowden extruders and located them to the stock mounting holes made in the chassis for the pro models and used a left and right kit like these.
http://www.ebay.com/itm/252333918249?_trksid=p2057872.m2749.l2649&var=551178733223&ssPageName=STRK%3AMEBIDX%3AIT
Some cutting of the plastic case may be required if you want easy access.

Pull back all the wiring from the original carriage and leave only the power wires for the heating elements. Plug in the extruder steppers and the feed from the Main CPU to the old carriage circuit board. Now run the thermistor feeds from the carriage circuit board to the carriage, add the 12v run for the permanent power to the heat sink fan from the main CPU, and run a feed for the layer cooling fan from the circuit board to the carriage. Zip tie together the heater, thermistor, and cooling fan wires and feed them all threw your cable chain to the carriage. Now pull back all the excess wires that fed the extruder steppers and ran to the carriage circuit board for the thermistors and zip tie it neatly in the motherboard compartment.

this is as far as I have gotten... Stay tuned for extruder alignment and position settings.

description.text:
This is an Omni Wheel set for making omnidirectional robots/rc vehicles. The wheel has a 65mm diameter, and the hub is designed to be mounted on 1/4" hex shafts (like tool bits). The wheel can be used as a single wheel or in pairs/sets with the rotated hub as pictured.

I used two layers of 10mm heat shrink tubing as the grip surface on the small roller, though silicone or other coatings can be used. There is also a larger roller to use as a bare plastic roller where grip is not essential. Large paperclips were used as the roller shafts. Three holes for #8-32 machine screws, though I also recommend super glue especially in the spokes for additional reinforcement if the wheel is going to see much impact.
I need a box to hold some of the tools that I had laying around, I wish I would have made some things a bit bigger. I may do that in the next version.

description.text:
I designed this as a foot for the corners of a friend's Delta. Worked out great. He glued a rubber washer to the underside of his, so I made a second model with an indentation for a rubber washer. The indentation 26mm diameter, and 1mm deep indentation just to help retain what ever piece of rubber (or flex filament) you decide to glue in there. I'd recommend a 1 inch by 3/8ths rubber washer but no guarantees that that will be perfect. I printed it in the other orientation previously, but I think this orientation will work out better. Overall, it gives 13.5mm of extra height to the printer. It has a slot for the V-rail, and takes two M4x10mm bolts and square nuts per foot. It also gives a nice concealing shell for wires to feed down the tubes of the extrusions for the top or the bottom of the printer if you're into that sort of thing.

I hope you enjoy them!

description.text:
I originally made this turntable to automate structured light scanning with "DAVID Laserscanner 4". But since the table is accessed via the serial port, it should be useable with a great number of scan setups.

At the heart of the turntable are a ChipKit Uno32, an Adafruit motor shield and a NEMA17 step motor.
Complete build instructions and firmware are available here:
https://sites.google.com/site/janbeck/3d-scanner-turntable-for-david4

Since then, the new version (DAVID5 has been bought by HP and is now HP 3DScan) has removed serial port support and a little more work is necessary to get the table to work there, but no firmware change is required:
https://sites.google.com/site/janbeck/3d-scanner-turntable-for-david5

I printed this using ZIRO CarbonFiber filament which gives a nice matte finish that is very functional for this application.

title: Scrap Paper Notepad Holder
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I use stacks of cut up scrap paper held together with a rubber band as notepads. This notepad holder still uses a rubber band, but it makes the notepad easier to use.

This is sized for paper that is approximately 4.25" x 3.67". That's one standard sheet cut into 6 pieces. See the picture for an example of how to cut. There is a bit of extra space on the edges, so your cuts don't have to be precise.

Stick your stack of paper under the flap and use a rubber band to secure it. The design allows it hold your paper firmly whether you have a full stack or just one piece of paper left.

Printer Brand:

Wanhao

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2

Notes:

1.2mm shell to make sure the hinge pin is strong

Print it the way the file is oriented. The notepad is not symmetrical. If you print it on the wrong side, the hinge may be fused together in the first layer

I included 3 files with different clearances for the print-in-place hinge - 0.3mm, 0.5mm, and 0.7mm. 0.3mm worked perfectly for me (just wiggle the hinge a bit to break it free), but use the others if you have problems.
